screens.name: Screen_10W10_Win_10_Launch_Recovery_Options_From_Advanced_Boot
screens.label: Screen 10W10.Win 10 Launch Recovery Options From Advanced Boot

fields.name: Screen10W10_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Win 10 Launch Recovery Options From Advanced Boot

Back up your files with File History Before attempting a refresh or reset of your operating system to factory condition, it is highly recommended that you back up your data using File History. Learn more about File History at Microsoft's Back up your files page. From the "Troubleshoot" screen in the "Advanced Boot and Recovery Options", click the appropriate option: 1. Refresh your PC: Windows Refresh will reinstall OS files and settings while keeping the customers data. Any applications or device drivers added after initial setup may need to be reinstalled. OS settings such as network connections and display preferences will also need to be re-established. 2. Reset your PC: Windows Reset will completely remove the current operating system, settings and data and reinstall a fresh copy of Windows. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have not backed it up on separate media. 3. Dell Backup and Recovery: Use this option if the original Dell factory image or a previously backed up image is available. This option will erase all data. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have

fields.name: Choose_Windows_Refresh_or_Reset_option_W10
fields.fieldText: Choose Windows Refresh or Reset option

screens.name: Screen_11_Win_10_Determine_which_startup_item_or_service_is_causing_the_issue
screens.label: Screen 11. Win 10 Determine which startup item or service is causing the issue.

fields.name: Screen11_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Win10 Determine which startup item or service is causing the issue.

If the issue is not present after reboot, you will need to re-enable services and startup items one by one until the cause of the issue is identified. One strategy is to enable half of the startup items and/or services and test to determine which half the problem is located. Continue to divide the remaining items in half until the problem is narrowed down. The startup items can be disable individually within the Task Manager 1. In the System Configuration Utility, click the Startup tab 2. Click on Open Task Manager. 3. Click on the startup item then click Disable in the lower right corner. Determine which application or device the startup or service belongs to. 1. If a startup or service was identified, determine the application or driver that installed it by reviewing the "Manufacturer" and/or "Location" information. If necessary, perform a search on the startup or service in Oracle Info Center or the web to help determine the parent application or driver. 2. Uninstall the identified application or device drivers and check for Stop Error 3. Determine if the application or device is Dell supported To return the Boot Process to a Normal Startup In MSCONFIG 1. In the search box (Cortana), type "msconfig then click OK. 2. Click the General tab. 3. Click Normal startup. 4. Click OK. 5. Click Yes when you are prompted to restart your computer. Does the startup/service belong to an application or a device?

fields.fieldText: Choose one

screens.label: Screen 12.2.1 - Make sure that there are no pending updates from Microsoft

fields.name: Screen_12_2_1_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Make sure that there are no pending updates from Microsoft

Note: If you’re having problems with Windows Update, the Windows Update Troubleshooter might be able to automatically fix the problem. Click Download and run the Windows Update Troubleshooter. Note: Also ensuring that no huge amount of data was restored on the system recently which may take time to be indexed by Windows.

fields.name: Did_performing_Windows_updates_resolve_the_issue

screens.name: Screen_12_3_1_Disable_MSI_for_the_controller_in_the_registry
screens.label: Screen 12.3.1 - Disable MSI for the controller in the registry

fields.name: Screen12_3_1_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Disable MSI for the controller in the registry.

1. In the same properties window opened in step 1.2, navigate to the Details tab and select Device instance path from the Property drop-down menu. Note this path. 2. Open the registry editor by typing regedit in the previously opened command prompt. 3. Navigate to: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Enum\PCI\\Device Parameters\Interrupt Management\MessageSignaledInterruptProperties, where refers to the device instance path you noted in step 2.1. 4. Change the value of the MSISupported key from “1” to “0”. 5. If you don’t know which controller your boot device is attached to, repeat steps 2.1 through 2.4 for all AHCI controllers found under 1.2.

fields.name: Does_making_the_registry_change_for_MSI_controller_resolve_the_issue

screens.name: Screen_18_2_0_How_to_generate_DTC_URL_link
screens.label: Screen 18 2.0 - How to generate DTC URL link

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content1
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

How to generate DTC URL link:

1. Click on http://dtcprov.hfn-inc.com/dtcAgent/login.php 2. Enter agent phone id and password to login.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content2
fields.fieldText: 3. Type the Customer Number, Order Number, Customer email ID, Customer County, Date od DTC Order, Select the SKU customer has purchased, Online Backup Capacity and Contract End Date.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content3
fields.fieldText: 4. Click on Copy URL and share the URL to customer.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content4
fields.fieldText: 5. Educate customer to follow the onscreen instructions. 6. Download, Save and Run DellClick2FixPlus.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content5
fields.fieldText: 7. Click on Next.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content6
fields.fieldText: 8. Accept the License Agreement and click on Next.

fields.name: Screen18_2_0_Content7
fields.fieldText: 9. On the Welcome page, Click on Start System Analysis.

fields.name: Screen18_2_Content2
fields.fieldText: 2. Click on "Advanced Troubleshooting". NOTE: Scroll down to see more options.

screens.label: Screen 1.0 Verifying if SupportAssist is installed on the system

fields.name: SupportAssist_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Verifying if SupportAssist is installed on the system

Type Appwiz.cpl and press Enter. 4. The Programs and Features window displays the list of programs that are installed on the system. 5. Check if Dell SupportAssist is displayed and it is the latest version (3.0.X.XXX).

screens.name: Screen_1_223_1_Check_the_system_hard_drive_and_memory_specifications
screens.label: Screen 1.223.1 - Check the system hard drive and memory specifications

fields.name: Screen_1_223_1_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Check the system hard drive and memory specifications

Both system memory and hard drive specifications can have a significant effect on expected performance. Even while meeting Microsoft's minimum hardware requirements, systems configured with a 5400 RPM hard drive and/or only 4 GB of system RAM can experience slow performance while starting up, shutting down or general operations. - Verify the hard drive speed. The drive model can be identified via Dell System Detect http://www.dell.com/support/home/us/en/19/Home/Index/QuickTest, or by getting the model number in Device Manager Disk Drive properties. (Type "Device Manager" in the Windows search box then click Device Manager from the search results. Click the + OR > next to Disk Drives.) - Verify System RAM. In the Windows search box type "System" then click on System in the search results. "Installed memory" should be located under the "System" section of the page. Optimize the OS for the given system configuration and recommend upgrading hardware There may be a few optimizations that can be made to the system that will marginally help the overall performance of the system. It is still recommended to at least a 7200 RPM hard drive and/or at least 8 GB of RAM. Remove unneeded startup items. - Remove unnecessary startup items in Windows 8/8.1 and Windows 10. 1. Type Task Manager in the Windows search box then click System Configuration in the search results. 2. Click the Startup tab to see what programs run when your startup your computer. Choose the program which you want to modify (Programs that are not needed when the computer starts up). 3. Click either "Disable" or "Enable" in the bottom right corner of the screen. Finished. - Remove unnecessary startup items in Windows 7 1.Click the Start Button then in the "Open:" field, type "msconfig" and press Enter. 2. Click the Startup tab. 3. Uncheck the items you do not want to launch on startup. Note: When you have finished making your selections, click OK. In the box that appears, click Restart to restart your computer. Adjust System Settings for Best Performance Some of the Windows visual elements can be turned off to free up resources. Windows 8/8.1 and Windows 10 1. In the Windows search field type "System". 2. On the left hand side click Advanced System Settings. 3. Click the Advanced tab. 4. Under "Performance" click the Settings button. 5. Choose the option Adjust for best performance Windows 7 1. Open Performance Information and Tools by clicking the Start button then clicking Control Panel. 2. In the search box, type "Performance Information and Tools" then in the list of results, click Performance Information and Tools. 3. Click Adjust visual effects (Administrator permission required. If you're prompted for an administrator password or confirmation, type the password or provide confirmation.) 4. Click the Visual Effects tab, click Adjust for best performance, then click OK. (For a less drastic option, select Let Windows choose what’s best for my computer.) Additional Steps - Uninstall unused applications and remove unused files - Defragment the hard drive - Minimize the number of applications run at the same time

fields.name: Did_optimizing_the_system_improve_the_performance
fields.fieldText: Did optimizing the system improve the performance

screens.name: Screen_1_W7R_Win_7_Run_System_Restore_Within_Windows
screens.label: Screen 1 W7R : Win 7 Run System Restore Within Windows

fields.name: Screen_1_W7R_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Start System Restore Within Windows 7

1. Log on to your computer as an administrator. 2. Open the Control Panel by clicking Start, and then clicking Control Panel. 3. Click System and Security, and then click System. 4. Under the Control Panel Home menu, click System protection. 5. If you are prompted for an administrator password, type your password. If you are asked for confirmation, provide confirmation. 6. Click System Restore. "Recommended Restore" is the default choice. This restore is the most recent restore point and the best place to start. To choose a different restore point, click Choose a different restore point, click Next and then click a restore point. 7. Click Next, and then click Finish to confirm your restore point. 8. To start the restore process, click Yes. Once the system restore is complete, your computer will restart. If the most recent restore point doesn’t resolve the issue, select the next restore point. Any software installed after the restore point will be lost and you'll need to reinstall it.

fields.name: Was_System_Restore_able_to_revert_to_an_earlier_restore_point

screens.name: Screen_1_Win_8_8_1_Launch_Recovery_Options_From_Advanced_Boot
screens.label: Screen 1. Win 8/8.1 Launch Recovery Options From Advanced Boot

fields.name: Screen_1_w8_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Back up your files with File History

Before attempting a refresh or reset of your operating system to factory condition, it is highly recommended that you back up your data using File History. Learn more about File History at Microsoft's Back up your files page. 2. From the Troubleshoot screen in the Advanced Boot and Recovery Options, click the appropriate option a. Refresh your PC: Windows Refresh will reinstall OS files and settings while keeping the customers data. Any applications or device drivers added after initial setup may need to be reinstalled. OS settings such as network connections and display preferences will also need to be re-established. b. Reset your PC: Windows Reset will completely remove the current operating system, settings and data and reinstall a fresh copy of Windows. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have not backed it up on separate media. c. Dell Backup and Recovery: Use this option if the original Dell factory image or a previously backed up image is available. This option will erase all data. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have not backed it up on separate media. Note: In most cases Refresh/Reset will finish without user intervention however if Windows needs missing files, it may be necessary to provide installation media i.e. DVD or thumb drive.

fields.name: Screen217_content1
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Perform a Disc Defragmentation

1. Use the Start menu to navigate to the Control Panel. Access the Start menu by clicking the Windows flag in the bottom-left corner of your screen. Look for "Control Panel"

fields.name: Screen217_content2
fields.fieldText: 2. In the Control Panel, select "System and Security". The "System and Security"

fields.name: Screen217_content3
fields.fieldText: 3. Select "Defragment and optimize your drives." Find the link in small text beneath the "Administrative Tools" heading.

fields.name: Screen217_content4
fields.fieldText: 4. Select your hard drive and click Analyze. Note that if you have a SSD, this option is grayed out and not available.

fields.name: Screen217_content5
fields.fieldText: 5. Check the percentage of fragmented files in the results.

fields.name: Screen217_content6
fields.fieldText: Note: There's no hard and fast rule about how fragmented your drive should be before you defrag it. You might want to keep your fragmentation percentage under 5% or so, however, so that the defragmentation process doesn’t take too long to finish. 6. If you want to defragment your drive, click Optimize. It's best to do this when you don't need to use your computer for anything else, so you can let Windows defragment the drive efficiently.

fields.name: Screen217_content7
fields.fieldText: 7. When Windows is done, your drive should say 0% fragmented in the Optimize Drives utility.

Windows 8 Reset

After clicking Remove everything, Windows may ask you to choose an Administrator account. Choose an account that has administrative privileges and provide the password then click Continue. 2. On the screen listing what the process will accomplish click Reset. 3. Choose to either "Just remove my files" or "Remove files and clean drive". Choosing the second option will take much longer and is only recommended if the user wants to insure all data was securely removed. 4. Follow the onscreen instructions to complete the rest of the process. Note: Windows Reset will remove any user data and applications. If data backup is required, select No and continue to Windows 7, 8, 10 OS Installation/Restore which has data backup options.

fields.name: Screen22b_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Check the BIOS for correct Boot sequence setting

Normally the one time boot menue can be accessed by pressing the F12 key at the Dell splash screen. If there is a problem using the one-time boot menu, review the boot settings in the BIOS to make sure they are configured properly. Solution service Motherboard will have their Boot settings in BIOS defaulted to legacy mode. (Reloading the BIOS default settings will also put the boot settings into legacy mode). The legacy mode is required to support Windows 7 and other non-Windows OS. 1. Press F2 at POST screen to enter BIOS setup. 2. Select General -> Boot Sequence 3. Insure USB Storage Device and/or CD/DVD/CD-RW Drive is configured as a boot device. Note: • Windows 7 and below usually are set for “Legacy Mode” + enabled "Legacy Option ROMs" Windows 8, 8.1 and 10 are normally set for "UEFI Mode“ + disabled "Legacy Option ROMs" Verified correct boot sequence.

On the screen listing what the process will accomplish click Reset. 3. Choose to either "Just remove my files" or "Remove files and clean drive". Choosing the second option will take much longer and is only recommended if the user wants to insure all data was securely removed. 4. In the event the system cannot boot to the Advanced Startup and Recovery Options directly from the hard drive, they can be accessed via the Windows 8 installation media or previously created recovery media. To access the Recovery Options via media, perform the following steps. From the Windows Installation DVD, Recovery Disk or USB recovery media 1. Shut down the computer 2. When press your computer's Power button and watch for the Dell logo to appear. 3. When the logo appears, press the F12 key to load the Boot menu. 4. If this menu does not appear, try restarting your computer again and pressing F12 several times when the Dell logo appears. 5. Once the Boot menu opens, select the optical drive with the Windows installation disk and press Enter. Or, if using a USB drive boot to USB. 6. When Windows 8 Setup appears, confirm that the Language, Time, Currency and Keyboard Method fields display the correct settings.

After clicking Remove everything, Windows may ask you to choose an Administrator account. Choose an account that has administrative privileges and provide the password then click Continue. 2. On the screen listing what the process will accomplish click Reset. 3. Choose to either "Just remove my files" or "Remove files and clean drive". Choosing the second option will take much longer and is only recommended if the user wants to insure all data was securely removed. 4. Follow the onscreen instructions to complete the rest of the process. Note: Windows Reset will remove any user data and applications. If data backup is required, select No and continue to Windows 7, 8, 10 OS Installation/Restore which has data backup options.

screens.name: Screen_5_211_Perform_ePSA_to_confirm_hardware_functionality
screens.label: Screen 5.211 Perform ePSA to confirm hardware functionality.

fields.name: Screen5_211_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Perform ePSA to confirm hardware functionality.

Dell Enhanced Pre-Boot System Diagnostics (ePSA) are diagnostics that are built into the hardware of your system. These tests allow you to check the hardware of your system from outside the Windows® operating system removing software from the diagnostic process. To run ePSA, perform the following steps: For Dell Desktop or All-In-One 1. Restart the computer 2. As the computer boots, press F12 when the Dell Splash Screen appears 3. At the One Time Boot menu, press the arrow key to highlight Diagnostics and press enter 4. A graphical menu, listing all the discovered devices in the system is now displayed and the express diagnostics will run Note: Takes about 4 minutes to complete For Dell Portable: 1. Shutdown the computer. 2. Press and Hold the Fn key while pressing the power button, then release both. 3. A graphical menu, listing all the discovered devices in the system is now displayed and the express diagnostics should run. 4. If the diagnostics fail, make a note of the error code. 5. Based on the diagnostic findings, the code will assist you in troubleshooting the fault. Note: Takes about 4 minutes to complete. For Portables if the above step doesn't help, you may follow as suggested for Desktops and All-In-Ones. If you dispatching against an ePSA code , you must use the Dell Code Validation tool. 1. Go to https://satc.dell.com/#/ 2. If this is your first use enter your settings preferences. 3. Ensure any popup blocker is disabled for this site. 4. Input the Service tag and click search. 5. Enter the ePSA code and validation code then click submit. 6. Record the ePSA error code and the validation code in your log.

fields.name: Are_there_any_errors_after_performing_ePSA_v2

screens.name: Screen_5_73_Determine_if_the_issue_is_related_to_a_connected_peripheral_device
screens.label: Screen 5.73 Determine if the issue is related to a connected peripheral device.

fields.name: Screen5_73_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Determine if the issue is related to a connected peripheral device.

Desktops: 1. Disconnect all peripherals except for the display, keyboard and mouse. 2. Attempt to recreate the reboot/shutdown/lockup with all devices disconnected. 3. If no peripheral appears to cause the issue, if possible, test with a different mouse and keyboard. Notebooks: 1. Disconnect all externally connected peripherals. 2. If the system is connected to a docking station, disconnect from the dock and connect the notebook's AC adapter. 3. Attempt to recreate the reboot/shutdown/lockup with all devices disconnected. Examples of devices that may be connected: 1. Printers 2. Scanners 3. Media card readers 4. Small media cradles (iPod, PDA, and MP3 player) 5. Digital cameras and video recorders 6. USB storage devices

screens.name: Screen_5_75_Information_regarding_customer_removable_parts
screens.label: Screen 5.75 Information regarding customer removable parts

fields.name: Screen5_75_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Information regarding customer removable parts

In most cases the root cause of the issue can be narrowed down to a single component through isolation troubleshooting. Customer replaceable units are designed to be easy to service. A screwdriver is the only tool that may be needed for some systems. Any accidental damage that occurs throughout the troubleshooting process with a Dell support agent will be covered by the warranty. Note: CRU component isolation is mandatory unless there is an approved exception documented. For more information see the below CRU policy documents • Handling Customers Who Refuse To Troubleshoot - Dell Global Policy - PNP13298 • CRU/MCSR Replacement Policy - Dell Global Policy - PNP15722

screens.name: Screen_5_78_Inform_user_of_proper_safety_procedures
screens.label: Screen 5.78 Inform user of proper safety procedures

fields.name: Screen_5_78_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Inform user of proper safety procedures

CAUTION: Anytime the Customer Replaceable Units (CRU) are removed, instruct the user to do the following: 1. Disconnect the AC adapter from the system. 2. Hold the power button for 10 seconds to discharge any remaining power. 3. Before touching any internal components the user should touch an unpainted metal surface to eliminate any static charge. This guide will provide generic information about which CRUs need to be disconnected/removed throughout the troubleshooting process. For system specific information refer to the user’s system configuration in Delta and keep a Training page open with the system specific teardown information. For system specific information, follow these steps: 1. Go to http://prm.dell.com/catalogload_productreference.html 2. In the search box enter the system model number. 3. Click the model of your system. 4. On the left pane, in the field service information section, expand Disassembly and Reassembly

fields.name: Screen5_79_Content

Procedure

Remove CRU's and try Minimum to Post

CAUTION: Anytime the Customer Replaceable Units (CRU) are removed, instruct the user to do the following: 1. Disconnect the AC Adapter from the system. 2. Remove the system battery. Use Training below for instructions. 3. Hold the power button for 10 seconds to discharge any remaining power 4. Before touching any internal components the user should touch an unpainted metal surface to eliminate any static charge. This guide will provide generic information about which CRUs need to be disconnected/removed throughout the troubleshooting process. For system specific information refer to the user’s system configuration in Delta and keep a Training page open with the system specific teardown information. For system specific information, follow these steps: 1. Go to http://prm.dell.com/catalogload_productreference.html. 2. In the search box enter the system model number. 3. Click the model of your system. 4. On the left pane, in the Field Service Information section, expand Disassembly and Reassembly Note: If System has multiple memory sticks then try with single memory at a time to isolate the issue

fields.name: Screen_8a_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Unable to identify the problem with the System Configuration Utility

Insure all services and startup items are re-enabled then continue troubleshooting. This procedure is critical in avoiding unnecessary OS reinstalls and part dispatches due to possible confusion caused by disabled startup items. If the customer is wary about unchecking items, let them know this is just temporary and is a check to see if a TSR (startup item) or service is causing the issue. Note: The agent is required to get a confirmation from the customer before uninstalling any application from the customer’s system. Continue troubleshooting without MSConfig

fields.name: Screen8b_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Advanced Options Boot Method

Choose if media will be used to access the Advanced Boot Options. Without Media • Advanced Boot Options for Windows 7 • OS Recovery Options or Advanced Boot Options for Windows 8/8.1 • Support Assist Service OS, OS Recovery or Advanced Boot Options for Windows 10 With Media • System Recovery Options menu for Windows 7 • OS Recovery Options or Advanced Boot Options for Windows 8/8.1 • OS Recovery or Advanced Boot Options for Windows 10 In most cases media is not required to access the Advanced Boot Options and makes sense to attempt that method first. However, there may be circumstances where the system will either not boot to the Advanced Options or Media will be required to complete a troubleshooting process after the Advanced Options Boot. If how-to instructions are not needed for Advanced Boot, choose Skip instructions to bypass the steps

Insure all services and startup items are re-enabled then continue troubleshooting. This procedure is critical in avoiding unnecessary OS reinstalls and part dispatches due to possible confusion caused by disabled startup items. If the customer is wary about unchecking items, let them know this is just temporary and is a check to see if a TSR (startup item) or service is causing the issue. Note: The agent is required to get a confirmation from the customer before uninstalling any application from the customer’s system. Continue troubleshooting without MSConfig

screens.name: Screen_8W8_Win_8_8_1_Launch_Recovery_Options_From_Advanced_Boot
screens.label: Screen 8W8. Win 8/8.1 Launch Recovery Options From Advanced Boot

fields.name: Screen8W8_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Back up your files with File History

Before attempting a refresh or reset of your operating system to factory condition, it is highly recommended that you back up your data using File History. Learn more about File History at Microsoft's Back up your files page. 1. From the Troubleshoot screen in the Advanced Boot and Recovery Options, click the appropriate option a. Refresh your PC: Windows Refresh will reinstall OS files and settings while keeping the customers data. Any applications or device drivers added after initial setup may need to be reinstalled. OS settings such as network connections and display preferences will also need to be re-established. b. Reset your PC: Windows Reset will completely remove the current operating system, settings and data and reinstall a fresh copy of Windows. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have not backed it up on separate media. c. Dell Backup and Recovery: Use this option if the original Dell factory image or a previously backed up image is available. This option will erase all data. It is important to reconfirm with the customer that all of their personal data will be lost if they have not backed it up on separate media. Note: In most cases Refresh/Reset will finish without user intervention however if Windows needs missing files, it may be necessary to provide installation media i.e. DVD or thumb drive. AnswerFlow Feedback

fields.name: Choose_Windows_Refresh_or_Reset_option
fields.fieldText: Choose Windows Refresh or Reset option

screens.name: Screen_911_Troubleshoot_Dell_Supported_Application_or_Device
screens.label: Screen 911 Troubleshoot Dell Supported Application or Device

fields.name: Screen_911_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Continue Troubleshooting for the identified application or device

Continue troubleshooting for the identified application or driver associated with the identified startup item or service. Or if applicable, continue to follow the proceeding steps in the guided path. Application 1. Search Oracle Info Center for information on how to troubleshoot issues with the application. 2. If an adequate solution can not be found in Oracle, try searching the web for additional information. 3. If the application or device is not Dell OEM, try the manufacturers website or other support options. Device 1. Search Oracle Info Center for information on how to troubleshoot issues with the device or driver. 2. If an adequate solution can not be found in Oracle, try searching the web for additional information. 3. If the application or device is not Dell OEM, try the manufacturers website or other support options. Important! Unchecking a startup item or service in the System Configuration Utility is a temporary step to help determine the root cause. It is necessary to continue troubleshooting the application or driver the startup item is associated with to permanently resolve the issue. Ensure all services and startup items are re-enabled before completing the contact. This procedure is critical in avoiding unnecessary OS reinstalls and part dispatches due to possible confusion caused by disabled startup items. If the customer is wary about unchecking items, let them know this is just temporary and is a check to see if a TSR (startup item) or service is causing the issue. Note: The agent is required to get a confirmation from the customer before uninstalling any application from the customer’s system.

screens.label: Screen 9.01 - Check the Memory and Hard disk utilization

fields.name: Screen9_01_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Check the Memory and Hard disk utilization

Checking Memory Usage on Windows 1. Hold down Alt + Ctrl and press Delete . Doing so will open your Windows computer's task manager menu. 2. Click Task Manager. It's the last option on this page. 3. Click the Performance tab. You'll see it at the top of the "Task Manager" window. 4. Click the Memory tab. Checking Hard disk Usage on Windows 1. Open File Explorer. You can use the keyboard shortcut, Windows key + E or tap the folder icon in the taskbar. 2. Tap or click This PC from the left pane. 3. You can see the amount of free space on your hard disk The progress bar gives you a visual guide on how much you've used up already. Underneath that, you see the numbers

screens.name: Screen_9_Win_7_Determine_which_startup_item_or_service_is_causing_the_issue
screens.label: Screen 9 - Win 7 Determine which startup item or service is causing the issue.

fields.name: Screen9_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Win 7 Determine which startup item or service is causing the issue.

If the issue is not present after reboot, you will need to re-enable services and startup items one by one until the cause of the issue is identified. One strategy is to enable half of the startup items and/or services and test to determine which half the problem is located. Continue to divide the remaining items in half until the problem is narrowed down. 1. In the "System Configuration Utility", click the Startup tab. 2. To access individual startup items, click the Startup tab then tick the check boxes to enable/disable each one. 3. To access the individual services, click the Services tab then tick the check boxes to enable/disable each one. Determine which application or device the startup or service belongs to. 1. If a startup or service was identified, determine the application or driver that installed it by reviewing the "Manufacturer" and/or "Location" information. If necessary, perform a search on the startup or service in Oracle Info Center or the web to help determine the parent application or driver. 2. Uninstall the identified application or device drivers and check for Stop Error 3. Determine if the application or device is Dell supported To return the Boot Process to a Normal Startup In MSCONFIG 1. From the "Search programs and files" box (Click the "Start" button), type "msconfig" and press Enter. 2. Click the General tab. 3. Click Normal startup. 4. Click OK. Click Yes when you are prompted to restart your computer. Does the startup/service belong to an application or a device?

screens.name: Screen_9_Windows_Media_Availability
screens.label: Screen 9 - Windows Media Availability

fields.name: Screen_9_Content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Windows Media Availability

• Determine if the installation or recovery media for the version of Windows installed on the system is available • If recovery media is not available, it should be possible to create a recovery DVD on the system or another system with the same Windows version. • Important! If the option to boot to USB or Optical drive is not available in the Onetime Boot Menu, ensure the boot sequence in the BIOS are properly configured to boot to the selected media type. • When recovering from USB/DUSB, it may take several minutes to load. Please wait 3-5 minutes before retrying/rebooting. Windows 7 Repair Disk 1. Open Backup and Restore by clicking the Start button, clicking Control Panel, clicking System and Security, and then clicking Backup and Restore. 2. In the left pane, click Create a system repair disc, and then follow the steps. A blank writable DVD will be required. Administrator permission may be required. If you're prompted for an administrator password or confirmation, type the password or provide confirmation. Windows 8 Recovery DVD or USB Drive 1. From the Windows 8 Start screen, type recovery. 2. In the search results pane, click Settings, then Create a recovery drive. 3. If the option is not grayed out, check the box "Copy the recovery partition from the PC to the recovery drive." (Without it, only the system-repair tools will be copied and will not have full reinstall capability.) Click Next. 4. The tool will indicate how much capacity is required for the backup. The default media option is a bootable flash drive, but if one is not available, a CD or DVD can be used. 5. Follow the remaining prompts to complete the process. Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 USB Recovery drive 1. Swipe in from the right edge of the screen, and then tap Search. (Or with a mouse, point to the lower-right corner of the screen, move the mouse pointer up, and then click Search.) 2. Type "recovery drive" in the search box, and then tap or click "Create a recovery drive." Enter the admin password if required. 3. When the recovery drive tool opens, click "Copy the recovery partition from the PC to the recovery drive" check box if installation files are needed and available. Note: If the checkbox is greyed out, the install files may not be available. The recovery drive will include only the recovery tools and a bootable image. 4. Insert a USB flash drive into the system that is at least as large as the size indicated on the screen. 5. Tap or click the USB drive the recovery files will be copied to, then tap or click Next. Tap or click Create. 6. The recovery image and necessary recovery tools will be copied to your USB flash drive, which will take some time, depending on the PC speed and the size of the recovery image. 7. When the process is click "Finish" Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 Repair DVD 1. To open the disc creation tool, open the "Run" box and type recdisc, and press Enter. 2. Insert a blank DVD and select the appropriate DVD drive. 3. Follow the on screen instructions to complete the process. Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 USB Recovery drive 1. Swipe in from the right edge of the screen, and then tap Search. (Or with a mouse, point to the lower-right corner of the screen, move the mouse pointer up, and then click Search.) 2. Type "recovery drive" in the search box, and then tap or click "Create a recovery drive." Enter the admin password if required. 3. When the recovery drive tool opens, click "Copy the recovery partition from the PC to the recovery drive" check box if installation files are needed and available. Note: If the checkbox is greyed out, the install files may not be available. The recovery drive will include only the recovery tools and a bootable image. 4. Insert a USB flash drive into the system that is at least as large as the size indicated on the screen. 5. Tap or click the USB drive the recovery files will be copied to, then tap or click Next. Tap or click Create. 6. The recovery image and necessary recovery tools will be copied to your USB flash drive, which will take some time, depending on the PC speed and the size of the recovery image. 7. When the process is click "Finish" Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 Repair DVD 1. To open the disc creation tool, open the "Run" box and type recdisc, and press Enter. 2. Insert a blank DVD and select the appropriate DVD drive. 3. Follow the on screen instructions to complete the process. Download and Create Installation Media Dell OEM Software including the Operating System media can be downloaded from Dell Download Center or Dell Digital Delivery. Use an appropriate DVD burning application to create media from the ISO Alternately for Windows 8/8.1 or Windows 10, the Microsoft Media Creation tool may be used. For information on using the Microsoft Media Creation Tool for Windows 8/8.1 and Windows 10 review the following OKB article: How to Create Windows Installation Media for Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 using the Media Creation Tool Purchase Media If none of the above options are available, the OS media can be purchased from Dell. Refer to the Dell-Branded Media Replacement Policy - Dell Global Policy for more information.

fields.name: Screen214_content
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Move files to another drive

Note: If you have photos, music, or other files that you want to keep but don't use very often, consider saving them to removable media, like a USB drive. You'll still be able to use them when the drive is connected, but they won't take up space on your PC. 1. Connect the removable media to your PC. 2. Open File Explorer from the taskbar and find the files you want to move. 3. Select the files, go to the Home tab, and then select Move to > Choose location. 4. Select your removable media from the location list, and then select Move.

screens.name: X5_214_Perform_ePSA_to_confirm_hardware_functionality
screens.label: 5.214 Perform ePSA to confirm hardware functionality.

fields.name: Procedure_Perform_ePSA_to_confirm_hardware_functionality
fields.fieldText:
Procedure

Perform ePSA to confirm hardware functionality.

Dell Enhanced Pre-Boot System Diagnostics (ePSA) are diagnostics that are built into the hardware of your system. These tests allow you to check the hardware of your system from outside the Windows® operating system removing software from the diagnostic process. To run ePSA, perform the following steps: For Dell Desktop or All-In-One Restart the computer As the computer boots, press F12 when the Dell Splash Screen appears At the One Time Boot menu, press the arrow key to highlight Diagnostics and press enter A graphical menu, listing all the discovered devices in the system is now displayed and the express diagnostics will run Note: Takes about 4 minutes to complete For Dell Portable: Shutdown the computer. Press and Hold the key while pressing the power button, then release both. A graphical menu, listing all the discovered devices in the system is now displayed and the express diagnostics should run. If the diagnostics fail, make a note of the error code. Based on the diagnostic findings, the code will assist you in troubleshooting the fault. Note: Takes about 4 minutes to complete. For Portables if the above step doesn't help, you may follow as suggested for Desktops and All-In-Ones. If you dispatching against an ePSA code , you must use the Dell Code Validation tool. Go to https://satc.dell.com/#/ If this is your first use enter your settings preferences. Ensure any popup blocker is disabled for this site. Input the Service tag and click search. Enter the ePSA code and validation code then click submit. Record the ePSA error code and the validation code in your log. Attention: SATC automatically returned ePSA error code : “NA", please make a note of this error code to use this in next screen/flow - ePSA diagnostic flow ". If you see the value is NA, please click on SATC tool link above and run manually on customer system to get the latest error code.
